Award.AwardTitle: CAREER:Structural, Spectroscopic, and Mechanistic Investigations of Native and Engineered Hemoglobin-Peroxidases
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Chemistry of Life Sciences Program funds Professor Reza Ghiladi of North Carolina State University for a CAREER award to carry out research entitled "Structural, Spectroscopic, and Mechanistic Investigations of Native and Engineered Hemoglobin-Peroxidases." This research involves probing the mechanism and expanding the substrate profile of dehaloperoxidase (DHP), the archetype of a potentially new and emerging class of bifunctional proteins known as the hemoglobin-peroxidases. DHP is the first globin identified to possess a biologically relevant peroxidase activity, and thus provides a unique system to explore our understanding of metalloprotein mechanism, activation, and design. Despite a number of studies on DHP that have helped to elucidate several of its mechanistic pathways, it is still not understood how this bi-functional protein can act as both a hemoglobin and a peroxidase. Biochemical assays, structural studies, and spectroscopic investigations (stopped-flow UV-visible, EPR, NMR, resonance Raman, and MÃ¶ssbauer) will be used to address questions pertaining to substrate binding and activation from both the peroxidase-active ferric and globin-active oxyferrous states. As tyrosyl radicals are implicated in mediating electron transfer in the DHP-catalyzed and H2O2-dependent dehalogenation of trihalophenols, low- and high-field EPR studies will be directed towards identifying the location of protein radical formation. Mutants of DHP will also be investigated for potential application in bioremediation against nitrophenol pollutants.

Metalloproteins play a central role in all living organisms, yet the governing principles of the metal-protein interaction continue to be of interest to scientists who are looking toward building paradigms for understanding metalloprotein structure-function relationships. When taken together, the research goals outlined within this proposal take advantage of the merits of a traditional bioinorganic approach that not only enable posing and addressing the types of questions about biological systems and life processes that are of interest to chemists, but can also potentially be of importance to areas outside of chemistry. These include addressing the fundamental issues of biocatalysis, enzyme mechanism, and de novo protein engineering, thus allowing for the advancement of areas as diverse as bioremediation, chemoenzymatic synthesis, and biomass conversion for renewable biofuel production. Additionally, the broader impacts resulting from the teacher-scholar activities supported by the integration of the proposed research plan with educational endeavors include the following: i) continue to provide rural K-2 and middle school science classrooms with demonstrations, lectures, and lessons plans for teachers on the chemistry of life processes through the "Creating STARS" outreach initiative; ii) continue the mentoring of talented, disadvantaged minority high school students for summer long research internships, using the structure-function relationship in metalloenzymes to introduce basic chemical biology concepts; iii) lead undergraduate and graduate chemistry students in interdisciplinary scientific inquiry that utilizes emerging techniques in molecular biology and spectroscopy that are becoming available to the next generation of bioinorganic chemists; iv) promote the placement of undergraduate students from low-income or outside-urbanization locations into multidisciplinary research labs as vehicles for broadening the participation of underrepresented minorities. This project is receiving co-funding from the Biomolecular Dynamics, Structure and Function Cluster in the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview. Over the past two decades, efforts in structural biology, molecular biology and genomics have provided us with an unprecedented ?chemical? view of biological systems. These systems provide many new and exciting opportunities to apply chemical principles to investigate biomolecular processes. One such example can be found in structural biology, where it is generally assumed that the function of a protein is closely linked to its three-dimensional molecular structure. This protein structure-function paradigm enables scientists to predict how a protein will perform based upon its structure, and underpins many of the advanced tools that scientists use to interrogate protein function. For proteins such as hemoglobin or the P450 enzymes found in the liver, this structure-function correlation is key to understanding their role in the chemistry of life processes. When a foundational principle such as the structure-function correlation fails for a specific protein, however, there is an urgent need to explore why, as it highlights that our understanding of such systems is still incomplete.

Intellectual Merits. Our work has focused on the enzyme dehaloperoxidase (DHP), a hemoglobin from the marine worm Amphitrite ornata. Beyond its oxygen transport function, DHP was known to have a peroxidase activity, a function essential to life that utilizes hydrogen peroxide to oxidize molecules. From the research performed in this CAREER award, we showed that DHP also possesses peroxygenase, oxygenase, and oxidase activities, with these three additional enzyme activities similar to those performed in the human body (such as the P450 liver enzymes, or the terminal respiratory enzyme cytochrome c oxidase). Given that these 5 total functions cannot be correlated to its structure, DHP is a recent example of a multifunctional protein that challenges many of the assumptions behind the traditional structure-function correlation. Remarkably, in a paradigm shift away from the traditional protein structure-function correlation, we have found that the substrate itself, and not the protein structure, plays a pivotal role in determining which enzyme activity is performed by DHP. We have termed this the Substrate Directed EnzymatiC Activity paRadigm ("SiDECAR"), and have now hypothesized that this new paradigm may be a common feature of a number of enzymatic hemoglobins. Thus, the work established here with DHP provides scientists with an unprecedented platform for deeply probing questions relating protein structure to the tuning of an enzyme?s activity. This work has been disseminated to the community through nine peer-reviewed publications, 31 seminars at US and international universities, 14 invited and contributed presentations at national and international conferences by the Principal Investigator.

Broader Impacts. The broader impacts supported by the integration of this research project with educational endeavors include the following: i) this research contributed to the training of four PhD and one MS graduate students, as well as three foreign research scholars from South Korea, in interdisciplinary scientific inquiry that utilized modern methods in protein structural characterization techniques; ii) four NC State University undergraduates conducted independent research using DHP; iii) five NSF REU summer undergraduates were mentored using DHP as a platform to introduce basic chemical and biological concepts; iv) 24 student presentations on DHP were given at local, regional, and national conferences; v) provided rural middle school science classrooms with outreach visits, demonstrations, lectures, and lessons plans for teachers on the chemistry of life processes through the "Creating STARS" outreach initiative; and vi) developed a cross-listed CH 403/CH 770 undergraduate/graduate "Special Topics in Bioinorganic Chemistry" course using the SiDECAR paradigm of DHP to introduce the protein-structure function correlation. More broadly, the knowledge gained furthered our understanding of the structure-function correlation in enzymes of marine origin in relation to terrestrial ones.
